context: Ending D: The Ghost — Specific choices made, beat Ghost in Act 4. The Driver becomes the new Ghost of Nova Pacifica.

lines.text: Night.
The harbor highway. Empty. Three lanes of black glass stretching toward a horizon that doesn't exist — just the place where the road stops being road and becomes sky.
One car. Moving like a whisper.

No headlights. No taillights. Just the sound — if you could even call it a sound. More like a pressure change. A shift in the air. The kind of thing you feel in your sternum before your ears catch up.
The car takes the harbor curve at a speed that shouldn't be possible on public roads. No tire squeal. No drama. Just physics bending politely out of the way.
A young racer — can't be older than nineteen — is heading home. Civic with a coffee-can exhaust and ambitions three sizes too big. The stereo is loud. The night is normal.
Then the headlights appear in the mirror.
Not headlights. Just... light. Faint. Getting closer in a way that doesn't make geometric sense, like the distance itself is wrong.
The car pulls alongside.
Three seconds. That's all.

The young racer turns to look. The driver's face is hidden — visor down, or maybe it's the angle, or maybe it's that the light doesn't work right around this car, like it's bending around something it doesn't want to touch.
Three seconds of silence inside a bubble of speed.
Then gone.
Not fast. Not in a burst of acceleration or a scream of engine. Just... gone. Like it was never there. Like the highway decided to keep a secret.
The young racer's hands are shaking on the wheel. The stereo is still playing but they can't hear it. The air smells like ozone and something older — gasoline and midnight and a dare.
Next morning. A garage. Three young racers, hoods up, wrenches out. The kind of morning where nobody's in a hurry.

lines.speaker: Young Racer
lines.text: I saw the Ghost last night. I swear.
The other two stop what they're doing. Wrenches go still.

lines.speaker: Racer's Friend
lines.text: Right. And I had dinner with Marcus Torres.

lines.speaker: Young Racer
lines.text: Harbor highway. Past midnight. It came out of nowhere. Pulled alongside me for maybe three seconds. No plates. No headlights. I couldn't see the driver.

lines.speaker: Racer's Friend
lines.text: What kind of car?

lines.speaker: Young Racer
lines.text: I... I don't know. I can't remember. It was dark and fast and then it was just gone.

lines.speaker: Racer's Friend
lines.text: Nobody sees the Ghost.

lines.speaker: Young Racer
lines.text: I saw the Ghost.
Silence. Oil dripping somewhere. A compressor cycling on.

lines.speaker: Third Racer
lines.text: My cousin says the Ghost used to be a real person. Someone who raced back in the day. Beat everyone. Beat Zero. Beat the whole city.

lines.speaker: Racer's Friend
lines.text: So what happened to them?

lines.speaker: Third Racer
lines.text: Nobody knows. That's the point. One day they just... weren't there anymore. But the car still shows up. Late at night. When nobody's watching.

lines.speaker: Young Racer
lines.text: It was watching me. I could feel it.

lines.speaker: Racer's Friend
lines.text: Watching you do what? Drive home at the speed limit?
They laugh. But the young racer doesn't. Eyes somewhere else. Somewhere on that highway, in those three seconds, where something looked at them and they looked back.
The camera cuts. Before the car is described. Before the make, the model, the color — before any detail that would make it real.
Because that's the thing about ghosts.
Legends don't have details. They have feelings.
And somewhere on the harbor highway, in the space between midnight and whatever comes after, a car moves like a whisper. No headlights. No name.
Just the road. Just the speed. Just the dark.
Forever.
THE GHOST
